posts.name: Mohammed
posts.cooked:
Hey everyone,

Recently our driving team were practicing on the robot and we had a technical issue with the elevator that may interfered with out LL4 camera (a hit or something), and all of the sudden we noticed that our pose estimation is notably incorrect, after some debugging we noticed that the MegaTag2 (green robot) in our limelight 4 is inverted and should be standing almost near the MegaTag1 pose (yellow robot), we checked the temperature of the camera, restarted pc, restarted robot, changed batteries… We checked the wiring and the cameras and everything seems to be fine, I currently can’t think of any reason of why this would happed all of the sudden and would appreciate it alot if anyone could help, Thanks.

I should also mention that everything was working correctly and perfectly fine with our pose estimation (even in our recent event)

posts.name: Evan Kruger
posts.cooked: We had this same issue earlier this week. Since MT2 is gyro infused, Either your gyro is calibrated backwards or your limelight offset is inverted

posts.name: Mohammed
posts.cooked:
flightpath24:

Either your gyro is calibrated backwards or your limelight offset is inverted

How could this be? everything was working fine then it happened all of the sudden, we recalibrated our gyro and still face the issue, the limelight’s offset is correct.

posts.name: Evan Kruger
posts.cooked: I’m not sure then. We had this issue because we told our third limelight it was looking out the front of the robot when it was actually looking out the back.

posts.name: Martin Nemaric
posts.cooked:
This is the EXACT same issue we had with MT2.

It would work perfectly (and provide super stable poses) 99% of the time. But every once in a while, it would basically reflect our robot poses “through” the april tag at the coral station. It wasn’t even an ambiguity flip, it was something else entirely. As you note, it has nothing to do with an incorrect orientation.

We ended up switching back to MT1 because we couldn’t figure out why it was happening, or how to fix it.

posts.name: Mohammed
posts.cooked:
Martini159:

We ended up switching back to MT1

We can’t change to MT1 it would change all the calculations we did previously because its not as accurate and we have an event in 2 days I don’t think we have time to redo everything, we want to complete our autonomous

We had a similar issue at some point where MT2 suddenly seemed to flip and put it in very awkward places. We spent a lot of time going through code, but it turned out to be an electrical issue where the pigeon lost power for a cycle and reset to 0. We use both MT and MT2 readings, and give the MT2 the poseEstimator angle, but it would take ages to converge. Our solution was to detect this happening and then lean on MT until we get a some number of MT poses, and then we add MT2 back

posts.name: Alex Tsekhansky
posts.cooked:
It’s IMU. We noted the same exact thing earlier.

If your IMU is generally on the “opposite” direction where your bot needs to be, and you ONLY see one apriltag with the camera, the MT2 always puts you on the “opposite” side of the tag. It’s if like the tag is transparent.

Note that this year the bots generally face TOWARDS drivers (vs away from drivers) when you start the matches. So for BLUE side we generally put IMU at 180 for the start and for the RED side - at 0.

And as I said, the behavior is specific to the situation then only one tag is seen.

posts.name: Mohammed
posts.cooked:
atsekhan:

So for BLUE side we generally put IMU at 180 for the start and for the RED side - at 0.

Can you provide a snippet of how you were able to do that?

posts.name: Alex Tsekhansky
Ertu

It wasn’t even an ambiguity flip, it was something else entirely. As you note, it has nothing to do with an incorrect orientation.

I am new to frc. I was wondering what app do you use for this simulation?
